title: Where's Huddles?
text:
Where's Huddles? is an American <a href="adult%20animation">adult animated</a> <a href="sitcom">sitcom</a> produced by <a href="Hanna-Barbera">Hanna-Barbera Productions</a> that premiered on <a href="CBS">CBS</a> on July 1, 1970 and ran for ten episodes as a summer replacement show for "<a href="The%20Glen%20Campbell%20Goodtime%20Hour">The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour</a>" until September 2.
It was similar in style to the studio's considerably more successful "<a href="The%20Flintstones">The Flintstones</a>", and used several of the same essential voice actors and plots. Also, like "The Flintstones", "Where's Huddles?" aired in the evening during <a href="prime%20time">prime time</a>, had a laugh track, and had somewhat adult themes. All ten episodes were produced and directed by <a href="William%20Hanna">William Hanna</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Barbera">Joseph Barbera</a>.
The summer replacement was intended be a trial run for a full prime-time series, but only lasted for ten episodes. The episodes were repeated on the network's Sunday afternoon special in the summer of 1971.
Overview.
The show's premise involved a professional football quarterback named Ed Huddles (voiced by <a href="Cliff%20Norton">Cliff Norton</a>) and his neighbor, the team's center Bubba McCoy (voiced by <a href="Mel%20Blanc">Mel Blanc</a>). They played for a team called the Rhinos. Other characters included Ed's wife Marge Huddles (voiced by <a href="Jean%20Vander%20Pyl">Jean Vander Pyl</a>), the Huddles' daughter Pom-Pom, and their <a href="black%20people">black</a> teammate Freight Train (voiced by <a href="Herb%20Jeffries">Herb Jeffries</a>). Bubba's wife Penny McCoy was played by comedic actress <a href="Marie%20Wilson%20%28American%20actress%29">Marie Wilson</a> in her final role. The regular <a href="foil%20%28literature%29">foil</a> was Claude Pertwee (<a href="Paul%20Lynde">Paul Lynde</a>), who lived alone with his cat Beverley and could tolerate the wives, but considered the men to be "savages". His look and temperamental behavior are similar to Mr. Peevly from "<a href="Help%21...%20It%27s%20the%20Hair%20Bear%20Bunch">Help!... It's the Hair Bear Bunch</a>".
The Rhinos' football announcer was voiced by sportscaster <a href="Dick%20Enberg">Dick Enberg</a>, who at the time was the voice of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a>. <a href="Alan%20Reed">Alan Reed</a> had a recurring role as Mad Dog Maloney, the Rhinos' coach. The Huddles had a dog named Fumbles, voiced by <a href="Don%20Messick">Don Messick</a>. Fumbles, much like Muttley, would often laugh at someone's misfortune, but whereas Muttley's laugh was wheezy in nature, Fumbles' laugh was more guttural. Most of the in-game action consisted of recycled animation (a shot of the team's running back side-kicking and stiff-arming defenders was one shot that was particularly frequently used).
Paul Lynde was credited for his role in this series as Claude Pertwee; this was unusual for Lynde, as he generally went uncredited in his other work for Hanna-Barbera at the time, which consisted mostly of <a href="Saturday%20morning%20cartoon">Saturday morning cartoon</a>s (as opposed to "Where's Huddles?", which aired in <a href="prime%20time">prime time</a>). In addition to the "Huddles" television series, there was also a comic book (with art by Roger Armstrong) which ran for three issues from <a href="Gold%20Key%20Comics">Gold Key/Whitman Comics</a> in 1971.
Home media.
On July 26, 2016, <a href="Warner%20Archive%20Collection">Warner Archive</a> released "Where's Huddles?: The Complete Series" on <a href="DVD">DVD</a> in region 1 as part of their <a href="List%20of%20works%20produced%20by%20Hanna-Barbera%20Productions%23Hanna-Barbera%20Classics%20Collection">Hanna-Barbera Classics Collection</a>. This is a Manufacture-on-Demand (MOD) release, available exclusively through Warner's online store.
The series will be available on <a href="HBO%20Max">HBO Max</a> in Fall 2021.
